Blog.post: Well, I went and did it. Bought 10 balls of Hazy at the sale.. It just looks so lovely and I know there are other patterns in the Tape Thing book that I'll want to knit. Am dithering over the Black Shadow since I know I'd wear black more often, but so far am resisting... so does anyone else have swatches to show? am curious how slipping knitwise vs. purlwise changes the look of the pattern, if at all... later!

Over the past few days I've been able to put in some time to starting Carla. I'm using Cotton Tape in urlLink Hazy . For the first time in a while, I'm not having any doubts about my colour selection. I'm really happy with this one! Yesterday I ended up wondering through a few shops, looking a early fall clothes and I found that Hazy coordinates with a lot of items that I was drawn towards. I didn't end up buying any thing to go with the sweater...that can wait until the sweater is completed. Back to the matter at hand...did I swatch for Carla? I had "swatched"**, however when I "swatched" I wasn't quite doing the pattern correctly. urlLink Here's an example of my fine skills of erroneously reading the pattern. See the knit stitches every third stitch? That's what you get when you risread where the asterisk is (ie: what stitches you should be repeating). It was truely mistfying me what I was doing wrong, until I re-read the pattern. The gauge of that 'swatch' is 10st to 10cm. I believe the target is 9st to 10cm. I figured that was close enough. Since figuring out where I went wrong, I've since reworked the section above the ribbing (ie: the back of the sweater) things are looking much better. This is much much better looking! Knitting this sweater is going take concentration as some have pointed out, because it will be difficult to find the stitches after frogging. So I'm being patient with this one! I'm a little worried that I'll run out of yarn. I always worry about that, but this time I quite nervous. I ordered one extra ball, just in case, but wonder if I should have played safe and gotten two. We'll see. When I finished my first ball I had knit 21cm of the back (including the ribbing band, which used more yarn). I'm going to lengthen the body by a few cm's as well as the arms to accomodate my height. Let's keep our fingers crossed. That's it for now! Tomorrow I've got a 4 hour car journey and maybe I'll be able to put a dent into the second skein while driving..however I'm a little nervous of taking this as a car project. ** I have a really bad habit of just starting the project and checking the gauge on the swatch once I've started. Notice that my erroneous swatch had a ribbing band on the bottom as well. tsk tsk!

i finally got around to swatching! it took a bit more time than it should have because i kept forgetting to yarn over before the slip 1, k1, psso. so annoying. hopefully after i cast on i'll have it in my brain. otherwise, i'll have to count my stitches after every row to make sure that i haven't forgotten to do it! i'm having second thoughts about the color i chose, string. (photos later) boy, is it dull. i thought i wanted something neutral. i had considered glint, but that shade isn't quite warm enough against my skin. argh. anyway, string it is! who knows? maybe i'll grow to love it! carla-alongers feel free to post to the blog through blogger. if for some reason you haven't received your blogger invite or need another one, please email me!

welcome to the Carla-along blog! this is a place for participants to share their progress, post photos, ask questions, and share tips on Carla from the Rowan booklet "It's A Tape Thing". please email urlLink me or urlLink lori if you would like to join us!

I spent the better part of last night finishing the front and back of Carla. Instead of dec. 3 stitches for the beginning of the Raglan decreases, I decreased two on each side by k3tog. Using this method I ended up with two extra stitches, but I couldn't come up with a way to dec. three stitches without breaking the pattern. I don't want the sweater to be baggy so I may end up frogging back and dec. 4 sts on either side. I am worried that this will make the sweater too tight (I normally wear a medium but I am knitting a small). I CO for the sleeves this morning and immediately the edge started to roll. Has anyone else had this problem? What method should I use to CO? Or ... Will the edge lay down by itself? I have also heard that once you unravel the stitches, your CO edge becomes very loose. Has anyone discovered a way to prevent this from happening?

On Friday evening I swatched for Carla, got lucky with the gauge, and started knitting the back piece while in the car on my way to an outing outside of the city the next day. This project just ROLLS! I finished the back piece last night and enjoyed knitting it. Lots of pictures for you to see have been published in urlLink an entry at my site . Here at the Carla-Along blog I have read about others coming up with extra stitches when finishing a row. Forgetting to slip the stitches over OR adding a yarn over right before the edge stitch is probably what is causing this. I did this a couple of times while knitting my swatch, and made note to avoid it when knitting the actual piece. As a result, I didn't have to frog once (thankfully!) .

Silly me! I picked up my Cotton Tape from my mum’s place on Saturday (I had it delivered there) and before then I had not seen the colour Electric ‘in the flesh’. I thought it would be a true, bright, royal blue. I had relied on the colour reproduction in the It’s a Tape Thing booklet and looking at shade cards on the web. And it turns out that Electric is not very blue after all! To my eye, it’s more of a lilac or a washed-out electric blue with pink undertones. I’m not disappointed; it’s still a vivid colour with a bit of ‘pizzazz’, which is what I wanted. I hope this of interest to others who might be trying to make Cotton Tape colour choices. Earlier in this blog Caroline noted that Shadow is actually greyish, not a deep black. Perhaps it’s the case that all the Cotton Tape colours (even the dark and vivid ones) have a slightly washed-out look? In this photo I have shown my Cotton Tape alongside the blue colour in some Marimekko fabric. I hope this shows how purple-ish the Cotton Tape is, when compared to a real blue. (Excuse the out of focus picture- my phone doesn’t take great photos).

Hi from Sally in Melbourne. Can I tell you about my colour choice for Carla? I was tempted to use the same colour as in the It’s a Tape Thing booklet. The warm chocolate-y brown of Sullen is divine. But since I think half the fun of knitting garments for yourself is choosing a colour other that the one(s) in the pattern, I decided to make a bold and brave colour choice for my version of Carla. I’ve chosen Electric, as it reminds me of the blue suede ankle boots I had in the 80s when I was a teenager. That electric blue makes me feel very nostalgic, for some strange reason. I never thought I’d get to the age when fashions from my teenage years would be back and I could relive being a teenager all over again (albeit in a more sophisticated, tasteful way!) So, through Carla, I hope to become emersed in a bit of 80s nostalgia. My Carla will be called “Blue Suede Carla”. Now, on to the knitting… (I’m casting on tomorrow). By the way, I’m knitting the 34” size (I’m more a 36”) because (as the wise knitters here have already noted) this stitch and yarn are sure to stretch widthways.

Last week I was able to finish the first body piece of Carla. The raglan decreases threw me for a bit of a loop the first time around, but I figured out that decreasing in twos (ie: k3tog) was key, so the second time around went much more smoothly! Yesterday I cast off the second body pieces and here's what they currently look like: Measuring the pieces has become a bit of a challenge, as the fabric is soooo stretchy. If I were more of a detailed oriented person, as some of you may be, I'd count the rows for each pieces so that you know you're knitting them identically. I didn't do this, nor do I currently have the patience to do it, so I'm hoping that it will all come out right in the end. So now I'm zipping along on my first sleeve: Not bad for only getting about an hour's worth of time knitting it last night. I had to remember urlLink Clara's post about the sleeve to know that I'm doing ok. It may not currently look like what the finished sleeve, but that's because of the dropped stitches that happen in the st-st part later.
